34.47.text: Elhanan Miller is the Arab Affairs Reporter

36.75.text: for the Times of Israel, a Jerusalem based Israeli

40.74.text: He holds a master's degree in Middle East History

43.14.text: and Islamic Studies from Hebrew University

45.24.text: where he completed a thesis that compared issues

48.05.text: of religion and state in Israel and Egypt.

51.46.text: He's also a contributing writer and editor

53.65.text: for Can Think, an Israeli website focusing

57.07.text: on Israeli and Middle East politics where he provides

59.10.text: personal insight on current affairs in Israel

63.54.text: Miller's active as well in inter-religious groups

66.27.text: with Palestinians in Jerusalem and has researched

68.76.text: the political aspects of the Palestinian refugee issue

72.14.text: as an Atkin Fellow at King's College in London.

75.92.text: Fluent in Hebrew, Arabic, and English, Miller

78.97.text: served as an Arabic linguist in the Israeli Defense Forces

81.80.text: Intelligence Core and has also worked as a translator

86.67.text: His opinion pieces have been published in publications

89.04.text: such as the Wall Street Journal and the Jerusalem Post

177.43.text: following a relatively long period of security calm

286.15.text: I think the semantics matter less than what's actually

289.72.text: happening and trying to describe what's happening.

294.44.text: on the Israeli side at least, not to belittle the loss

302.34.text: but when you take 10 people killed in Israel

309.08.text: that's probably less than one suicide bombing

316.66.text: So in terms of the scope of actual damage,

320.39.text: of actual casualties, the magnitude is much,

323.12.text: much smaller than what we've seen in the past.

340.65.text: So I'd like to try to characterize this wave

346.64.text: and say that it is reminiscent if we talk about

351.15.text: Intifada is the Arab word for uprising.

353.92.text: It is reminiscent of the first intifada

356.21.text: that plagued Israel and the Palestinian territories

358.76.text: between 1987 and approximately ended with the signing

363.10.text: of the Oslo Peace Accords in September 1993.

374.16.text: by Palestinians very much focusing on stabbings,

378.07.text: Molotov cocktails, stone throwing, and the like,

381.57.text: and in that regard, what we see now is very similar.

386.43.text: acting very much of their own volition.

398.31.text: the second Intifada this one seems to be unorganized

407.06.text: and they don't belong to any official recognized

417.18.text: the city, the Palestinian population in Jerusalem

1561.72.text: of the Israeli side, but he focused a lot on the media.

1564.69.text: And you see him on the Sunday, two days before

1569.05.text: his attack frantically trying to set straight

1572.22.text: the narrative of an Israeli, of the Israeli media.

1575.82.text: That Sunday a young woman was badly injured

1578.35.text: when she set off gas canisters which were in her car.

1584.33.text: These Israeli police said that she was on her way

1586.42.text: to perpetrate a huge terror attack in Jerusalem,

1589.16.text: was stopped by a policemen who suspected her driving

1592.04.text: and then she shouted allahu akbar and set off

1597.28.text: Muhannad Halabi was frantically, she was from his village

1600.89.text: and he was frantically saying don't believe

1602.68.text: what the Israeli media's telling you.

1604.18.text: It's all lies, I just spoke to her brother.

1606.94.text: She was on her way to University.

1608.39.text: She had nothing to do with it.

1611.10.text: So you have this contested version of what happened

1615.49.text: but also the sense that our voice isn't getting out there.

1619.85.text: That we have an efficient Israeli media and that our version

1623.51.text: even if Palestinian media's saying it or Arab media's

1630.70.text: He was also angry with his own co villagers.

1633.12.text: He was walking around his village,

1635.55.text: which is a suburb of Jerusalem and he sees

1637.34.text: all the shops open and people going about their daily

1640.72.text: Now a general strike was announced in the Palestinian

1644.77.text: territories and he says nobody's respecting that.

1647.41.text: People here have no respect for the lives

1649.23.text: of the martyrs on the Palestinian side who were lost.

1652.52.text: So he said people close your shops.

1656.86.text: There's no national leadership telling you

1660.83.text: This is an act that you have to do because

1662.54.text: we have no patriotic leadership and it's up to you

1665.91.text: to do it, to show respect.

1668.51.text: So he was very much disillusioned

1671.22.text: as I said the the Palestinian leadership

1673.91.text: and one of the quotes that I picked up from

1675.66.text: his Facebook page said, as the violence was already

1679.04.text: going on, he joined it a few weeks into it.

1681.35.text: He was saying, the reassuring thing is that the leaders

1685.99.text: The opportunists and those who love to appear

1687.59.text: on television screens will soon be marginalized.

1690.77.text: In other words, it's not the leaders who are starting this.

1693.55.text: This is very much a grassroots thing,

1695.63.text: this is coming from above, nobody tells us what to do.

1699.51.text: The revolution is in the hands of the people.

1702.65.text: One of the most maybe chilling things that people

1704.76.text: commented about was a Facebook post that he wrote

1708.52.text: one year before he carried out this attack.

1711.29.text: So one year ago he posted something called a will

1718.48.text: So a will, and he said number one on the list

1722.81.text: of 10 things that he told his family or people to do,

1726.73.text: was I instruct the factions, that is the Palestinian

1729.51.text: factions, Fata, Hamas, none of them should claim

1735.71.text: My death was for my homeland, not for you.

1738.28.text: Meaning I'm not dying for some sort of partisan causes,

1741.52.text: for some sort of political faction,

1743.58.text: I'm doing this for the sake of my homeland

1754.88.text: So these are the narratives of both sides.

1757.06.text: I went into some depth on the Palestinian perpetrators

1760.57.text: because those are the things that I was following

1762.43.text: as a journalist but I think that you know sometimes

1764.96.text: people don't really talk, they don't see it when

1767.46.text: they're involved in it and I'd like to give a little bit

1770.14.text: of context to what's been happening and maybe

1772.27.text: try to explain the violence not only in terms

1775.33.text: of Al-Aqsa in Jerusalem which is how people explain it

1777.84.text: to themselves, but also in terms of some of the

1784.23.text: So one issue that really needs to be taken into account

1786.33.text: is the collapse of the Palestinian political system.

1789.71.text: The Palestinian political system was never very strong

1792.88.text: from the time that it was formed in 93,

1795.72.text: but it really is going and went through an accelerated

1798.68.text: process of collapse when Hamas took over control

1806.14.text: A year after Israel withdrew from the Gaza Strip.

1808.95.text: So Hamas overthrew Mahmoud Abbas' Palestinian authority

1812.65.text: and took control, and since then for the last eight years

1817.70.text: you have two defacto authorities competing with

1821.38.text: each other, hating each other, undermining each other.

1825.80.text: If you ask Mahmoud Abbas how Hamas has tried

1828.29.text: to assassinate him, he said this to the Prince of Katar

1831.09.text: last year, officially to placate the people

1835.74.text: they formed a unity government of tecnokrats,

1839.33.text: not of members, but that was I think just a veneer

1843.73.text: of unity in order to placate the public

1847.97.text: with no real authority on the ground.

1851.58.text: The government Israeli met and today when the PLO

1855.10.text: or people from the west bank want to go to Gaza,

1856.99.text: Hamas simply blocks them and doesn't allow them in.

1858.83.text: When they were allowed in they got stuff thrown at them,

1862.64.text: threatened, they weren't allowed to leave the hotels

1864.45.text: that they were at in Gaza.

1865.78.text: So the division within the Palestinian body politic

1872.03.text: That's one and so the dissolutionment of some of

1874.84.text: these teenagers with their own Palestinian system

1878.06.text: is very much obvious from this especially in

1884.27.text: Secondly, and my ranking here is in no order

1889.82.text: This is just things that we should keep in mind.

1892.83.text: I'm not ranking them in terms of importance.

1896.36.text: For the last year and a half the Palestinians

1897.93.text: and the Israelis have not been negotiating.

1901.01.text: The last round that lasted nine months,

1904.03.text: led by Secretary Carey fell apart last April,

1908.72.text: April 2014 and has not been renewed since.

1912.48.text: There have been no real ties, negotiations,

1919.83.text: A few back channel conversations but nothing beyond that.

1925.57.text: And there doesn't seem to be an initiative

1929.84.text: President Obama gave a long interview to an Israeli

1933.24.text: television station a couple months ago, channel two,

1935.99.text: where he said basically that by the end of his term

1938.39.text: he's not going to try again to relaunch this

1942.39.text: and that the sides need to show that they're interested

1946.28.text: is not going to put more effort into a lost cause.

1949.35.text: So that's again something that's in the background

1953.28.text: and I think that the chemistry, the personal chemistry

1955.82.text: between our leaders meaning Prime Minister Netanyahu

1959.24.text: and Abbas is probably the worst chemistry at the moment

1963.77.text: than, that any Palestinian Israeli leaders have had

1968.50.text: certainly since, certainly for the last 15 years

1971.66.text: since the Camp David talks between Barack

1974.50.text: and Arifat fell apart under Bill Clinton.

1979.09.text: There was a lot of distrust then between Barack

1980.99.text: and Arifat certainly, but I think now we've reached

1983.80.text: basically the same point if not worse.

1988.98.text: I think another important issue is that this popular

1993.24.text: uprising is basically a vindication or a realization

1997.58.text: of Hamas' agenda for the West Bank.

2000.70.text: Since Hamas lost I would say or was vanquished

2005.14.text: by Israel last summer in what we call operation protective

2009.95.text: edge, none of its stated goals were realized by the time

2016.43.text: the cease fire was reached after 50 days of fighting.

2020.07.text: Hamas has really been trying to encourage

2022.76.text: a popular uprising in the West Bank and has been

2026.62.text: inciting Palestinians to do that and encouraging

2030.40.text: To take action themselves, not to wait for the leaders,

2032.57.text: not to be bound by political decisions by sell outs

2036.02.text: like Abass et cetera, this is Hamas saying.

2040.27.text: And so this is very much Hamas' plan materializing.

2046.90.text: Speaking of Facebook, a very interesting post by

2051.02.text: the deputy head of Hamas' political bureau,

2053.80.text: a man called Musa Bumarzuk, he's answering his critics,

2057.34.text: why aren't you firing rockets into Israel

2059.52.text: in solidarity with what's happening in the West Bank?

2061.59.text: Why aren't you supporting the efforts

2063.29.text: of the Palestinians in the West Bank?

2064.60.text: He says if we were to fire rockets we would only be

2067.74.text: deflecting attention from what's happening in

2069.25.text: the West Bank and reducing the legitimacy that

2072.96.text: the Palestinians there are having in the eyes of the world.

2075.67.text: We would be drawing attention to us and we would be losing

2080.15.text: We would be wasting our resources and only losing

2084.45.text: So we're going to sit this one out says Musa Bumarzuk

2087.75.text: and we're going to let the Jerusalemites

2089.02.text: and the West Bank people do their own thing.

2093.46.text: Of course in the background there's the issue

2097.53.text: Jerusalem officially a city that's been united

2099.87.text: for the last 48 years suffers from huge social gaps.

2105.35.text: It's very easy to tell apart a Jewish neighborhood

2107.61.text: in Jerusalem from an Arab neighborhood

2109.50.text: not only because by and large the populations don't mix.

2115.77.text: and Palestinian neighborhoods are very Palestinian,

2118.23.text: but the socio economic level differences between

2124.02.text: I mean, east Jerusalem is impoverished.

2127.26.text: It's better off than the West Bank because the people

2129.65.text: that work in Israel and travel freely,

2133.79.text: Nevertheless, they don't vote in Israeli elections,

2136.97.text: they don't vote for city hall voluntarily

2139.74.text: because they see themselves as Palestinians.

2142.01.text: So you have this huge gap.

2143.27.text: You have a divided, a defacto city that is divided

2146.16.text: in terms of national identities and social gaps.

2153.01.text: And I think it's also very important to realize

2155.55.text: the general background of this as well.

2157.70.text: You can't isolate what's happening in the Palestinian

2159.73.text: territories from the general Arab Spring

2167.16.text: have been inundated with images of Arab activism,

2170.64.text: of Suni Arab activism all around them,

2174.27.text: in all our borders from Egypt, to Syria, to Lebanon,

2178.47.text: to Libia, Yemen, everywhere around them Arabs

2183.40.text: are standing up and taking things into their own hands

2186.49.text: and Palestinians have not done that so far.

2190.19.text: So beyond the very specific context of our conflict

2193.12.text: there's also this feeling of urgency and partaking

2196.06.text: in something larger than just this.

2198.19.text: Of partaking in a general Arab awakening

2207.56.text: And maybe one last point is sometimes people are referring

2210.93.text: to the perpetrators, to the terrorists here

2214.30.text: What we mean by the Oslo Generation is a generation

2215.81.text: that was born following the signing of the Oslo Agreements,

2221.23.text: Most of the perpetrators are indeed under 21, 22 years old.

2223.90.text: These are people that didn't see the signing

2226.19.text: of the Oslo, they didn't agreements.

2230.05.text: They didn't experience the hope and that this conflict

2236.25.text: would end and many of them are even too young

2239.23.text: to remember the violence and the destruction that happened

2242.67.text: during the second Intifada from 2000 to 2002 primarily

2246.72.text: and how terribly Palestinians of course and Israelis,

2250.34.text: but on the Palestinian side how terribly Palestinians

2253.72.text: suffered as a result of an armed revolution.

2257.45.text: Especially when it was very, very violent

2262.33.text: So they don't see, they don't have a lived experience

2265.56.text: of the violence and of the damage that violence can cause.

2269.71.text: Their parents do, their older brothers might,

2272.15.text: but many of them don't, so we have to remember

2273.64.text: the age of these people as very important.

2277.10.text: A troubling image that appeared on Palestinian social media,

2283.84.text: So this is where I end with a question, is this the end?

2290.86.text: As we're speaking there are stabbings still happening

2293.14.text: on a daily basis which hadn't happened before October.

2298.41.text: I think from the Israeli side one of the troubling things

2300.88.text: is this sense among Israelis of inevitability.

2305.64.text: A sense that there's nothing really that can be changed

2310.93.text: It's almost seen as you know seasonal,

2313.37.text: as like some sort of tropical storm that we have to weather

2318.62.text: Because Israelis don't sense that there was a change

2321.93.text: in the status quo in Temple Mount and most of them

2324.07.text: don't even care what happens on Temple Mount

2327.80.text: they don't really see what operative steps

2330.11.text: the government can take, even if they have much criticism

2332.85.text: of the government for other policies,

2334.84.text: they don't really see what they can do this time

2336.99.text: in order to you know, make the violence less acute.

2342.53.text: So a sense of desperation is certainly

2347.54.text: And I don't know exactly how this will end

2354.47.text: given what it seems to be a certain lack of will.

2358.35.text: Certainly United States but maybe Europe

2360.72.text: is a little more interested this time around.

2363.70.text: So I think I want to stop here and open the floor

2375.34.text: - So we will now take questions.

2380.22.text: will come to you and preference goes to students

2395.16.text: and how he's sort of decided to sort of leave this

2401.69.text: towards the end of his presidency,

2404.82.text: to leave this issue and not really do much about it,

2408.99.text: how do you see the incoming presidential election

2414.41.text: - I haven't been following the American

2416.19.text: presidential election so closely, but the last thing

2418.77.text: that I heard that is in the Democratic debate

2420.65.text: there was almost no mention of Israel at all

2422.79.text: which is I think an indication of the fact

2425.59.text: that probably many Americans, especially on

2427.77.text: the liberal side have grown weary with the conflict.

2433.01.text: They don't want it to be part of their considerations

2436.38.text: Maybe they also see it as unsolvable.

2439.08.text: So I don't know if this is an indication of what will

2442.63.text: happen if the Democrats win the elections

2445.31.text: but I think understandably people don't see

2448.75.text: you know, a clear solution here and maybe have

2452.04.text: come to realize that the middle east has a whole array

2455.18.text: of problems and not necessarily many of them emanating

2460.50.text: I think the conflicts we see around the middle east,

2462.70.text: the uprisings are independent one of the other

2466.36.text: and I don't necessarily see them as based

2468.57.text: or as stemming from our conflict.

2470.48.text: I think they need to be addressed separately.

2476.48.text: The group that you didn't mention was the 20

2479.22.text: or so percent of Israelis who speak Arabic

2481.85.text: and identify as Palestinian and their narrative

2484.83.text: might be a lot more complex, but do you see their narrative

2490.38.text: or perhaps more or a hope for peace?

2494.83.text: - Well you're right, they're really stuck in the middle.

2498.69.text: I mentioned them in passing when I mentioned

2500.39.text: the Islamic movement in Israel and when I mentioned

2502.80.text: the Arab MK's, I think most of them because they have

2506.67.text: more interaction with Israeli Jews, they're more

2512.11.text: realistic about what can and can't be,

2516.51.text: I think most of them realize that there's no plan

2520.24.text: to destroy the mosques or the buildings on

2523.12.text: Temple Mount, but they do believe many of them do believe,

2526.44.text: and I think I was even surprised by how many believe

2529.33.text: that Israel does really intend to change

2532.90.text: the status quo on Temple Mount in a real way.

2537.51.text: And this just shows, this goes to the level

2540.04.text: of suspicion they have for mainstream politics

2542.37.text: in Israel and the level of, the low sort of level

2548.59.text: But I think also maybe shows somewhat a lack

2551.99.text: of understanding of what any government in Israel

2554.14.text: and especially this government can realistically do

2557.87.text: It's impossible for a government in Israel to change

2561.61.text: the status quo to allow Jews to pray on Temple Mount

2563.98.text: for example, it just won't pass.

2568.43.text: The whole Arab world will be up in arms.

2569.96.text: So even if you accept the libertarian sort of

2574.40.text: freedom of worship argument which I must say

2577.02.text: resonates with me even as someone who has no aspirations

2580.25.text: to pray there, even if you accept that narrative

2584.44.text: from a realistic point of view,

2586.69.text: the way Israel is situated in the Middle East

2588.81.text: and in the world, there's no real way

2590.55.text: for Israel to be able to do anything.

2592.69.text: But the fact that the many people in the Arab society

2596.32.text: is be it Palestinian or Israeli's don't realize

2598.14.text: that is a testament to the lack of,

2600.17.text: sort of dialogue and interaction I think.

2609.34.text: Could you give us some information or give us

2611.56.text: some perspective on both maybe if there's any context

2615.39.text: in Netanyahu's recent comments about the Palestinian

2617.98.text: motivating the holocaust and what the reaction

2622.56.text: in Jerusalem was to that statement on both sides?

2625.76.text: - What do you mean the reaction in Jerusalem?

2631.32.text: and in Israel and Palestine and the Jewish people

2635.50.text: and how they reacted to the statements by Netanyahu?

2639.30.text: - Okay maybe I'll just explain to those in the audience

2641.49.text: who weren't completely aware of this.

2645.09.text: This caused a huge splash in Israel about

2647.16.text: three or four days ago when during a speech

2649.75.text: Netanyahu spoke to a Zionist group I think

2654.04.text: of Americans in Jerusalem and he said that originally

2659.60.text: Adolf Hitler wasn't planning to annihilate the Jews

2662.16.text: but only to deport them and along came a very divisive

2666.78.text: and controversial figure called the Mufti of Jerusalem,

2669.41.text: a Palestinian leader in the 30s and 40s who was

2673.15.text: pro Nazi, that is known and he met with Hitler

2676.49.text: at the end of 1941 but there's no protocol of the meet,

2680.60.text: I mean there's no verbatim protocol.

2684.26.text: So according to Netanyahu's version in this speech

2687.38.text: he is the one that convinced Adolf Hitler

2689.58.text: that the proper solution to the Jewish problem

2692.20.text: would be annihilation rather than deportation.

2696.75.text: And his words, in Netanyahu's words,

2700.18.text: Hitler asks the Mufti what should I do with them

2703.11.text: and the Mufti answers burn them.

2705.90.text: Those were the, that's the exchange that Netanyahu quotes.

2708.98.text: Now this was, this was received with a very large amount

2713.51.text: of shock among not only Holocaust researchers

2716.24.text: but also mainstream public in Israel both on

2718.91.text: the left and on the right.

2721.06.text: People were kind of holding their heads in disbelief.

2723.55.text: As to how our Prime Minister could say something like that

2727.96.text: and basically revise, seemingly revise everything

2731.92.text: we know about the way the Nazi's functioned.

2738.43.text: Now it was received very badly.

2741.77.text: I mean the taxi driver who took me to the airport

2745.22.text: on the way here in Jerusalem said he thought Netanyahu

2749.08.text: He didn't think that Netanyahu meant

2750.66.text: that actually that's what he was using it as

2757.16.text: I mean that's the problem was, in his attempt

2764.56.text: to portray the Palestinians as intransigent

2766.98.text: and as associated with the Nazis which the man was

2769.61.text: historically, but he wasn't the person to initiate

2774.01.text: the final solution, what's known as the final solution.

2777.36.text: So that was I think a very misfortunate statement

2779.93.text: and the Palestinians obviously capitalized on it

2782.33.text: and said look how crazy and radical he is

2785.13.text: and he can't be reasoned with.

2787.93.text: So I think it'll be forgotten at least in the short term,

2792.25.text: people will move on, but I think it was a very bad move

2804.19.text: I was curious when you were showing the perpetrators

2809.00.text: and sort of talking about this violence,

2812.49.text: what would you recommend Palestinians do

2816.87.text: to stand up for their rights?

2819.38.text: There's no Palestinian army, their political system

2823.86.text: is shaky, and they're marginalized economically,

2828.49.text: how would you recommend someone trying to stand up

2832.81.text: for what they believe in, sort of get their message across?

2836.50.text: It doesn't seem like there's much for them.

2840.25.text: - Well I mean it really depends on when you say Palestinians

2842.57.text: which Palestinians you mean because there's

2845.97.text: under the people that define themselves as Palestinians

2848.28.text: let's say between the Jordan and the sea,

2850.98.text: there's three types of categories of citizenship

2855.59.text: The first is full Israeli citizens and they get

2858.75.text: to vote in the parliament and they live in Israel.

2861.87.text: The second category I'll say on the other side

2864.24.text: is people under the Palestinian authority.

2865.77.text: People who are not Israeli citizens at all

2867.13.text: but ruled by the PA centered in Ramala

2870.16.text: and the third, what seems to be the most involved

2872.55.text: in this round of violence are residents of Jerusalem

2876.31.text: who are middle category between those first two.

2879.02.text: On the one hand they enjoy resident status

2881.75.text: which means that they get full social

2888.09.text: They get medical coverage, social security coverage,

2890.06.text: and they get to vote in municipal elections,

2892.69.text: but they're not full citizens of Israel.

2896.14.text: Now those people have chosen for first of all,

2900.76.text: They can appeal and they can win citizenship if they choose

2902.98.text: but for ideological reasons which I'm not,

2906.39.text: I don't want to question or you know,

2909.33.text: it's not for me to decide for them what they do,

2911.71.text: but they've decided to cast their lot

2914.29.text: with the Palestinian cause and not vote

2920.00.text: and identify with the Palestinians to a great extent.

2924.66.text: So when you have a city hall for example,

2926.85.text: which is completely Jewish because the Palestinians

2931.49.text: are boycotting the elections then what you get

2935.78.text: is a skewed representation of the residents

2940.22.text: Jerusalem is a city that's divided 40-60.

2951.02.text: Now it's unjust that they don't get

2952.39.text: the same allocation of funds and that they don't get

2954.94.text: the same rights but the sad reality of Democracies is

2959.52.text: that when you have no representation

2961.63.text: then your rights get eaten away by other people

2966.26.text: So the people of Jerusalem specifically

2967.76.text: need to make a decision for themselves,

2972.09.text: either a tactical or a strategic decision

2975.86.text: They can keep demanding Jerusalem be the capital

2978.41.text: of the Palestinian state, the future state,

2981.97.text: because under most of the negotiation rounds

2984.09.text: that was the direction, but they might want

2987.86.text: to vote tactically and take part in the democratic

2991.27.text: process that they're legible to in order

2993.67.text: to take care of their rights in the short term.

2995.80.text: And that's something that they haven't decided to do.

2999.55.text: And unfortunately they get harmed by it.

3002.71.text: So I would say that the struggle has to do with

3005.45.text: what type of citizenship you belong to I would say.

3016.35.text: Now in the West Bank, okay, in the West Bank

3021.35.text: They're not, you know, there's other,

3026.05.text: there's a political process, they can decide,

3029.07.text: you know, what line their government wants to take,

3031.54.text: they can have an internal debate on whether Mahmoud Abbas

3036.23.text: is accepting or rejecting certain things

3038.08.text: in previous rounds of negotiation was a good idea

3042.12.text: I don't see that debate happening so much

3045.12.text: So first you have to decide what you're fighting for,

3047.65.text: specifically, are you fighting for the eradication

3049.40.text: of Israel as a whole as Hamas advocates?

3052.43.text: Hamas which won the elections of 2006

3054.58.text: by a majority or are you willing to recognize Israel

3058.72.text: as a state and then let's decide what specifically

3061.49.text: we're fighting for and then adapt your modes

3072.95.text: - [Woman] Thank you so much for your talk tonight.

3075.38.text: So as you mentioned, one of the reasons for this new

3077.92.text: spade of violence and kind of the cyclical violence

3082.46.text: that Arab citizens of Israel and other Palestinians

3085.86.text: in the territories have and their sense that it's

3089.49.text: intractable and nothing's going to change,

3092.96.text: but as we also saw in the Israeli elections

3095.19.text: in the last year, the Israeli public recently

3097.47.text: reaffirmed this status quo by bringing

3101.13.text: the Netanyahu government back into power

3103.64.text: and voting very heavily on the right.

3106.30.text: So I'm wondering, what in your opinion is it going

3109.66.text: to take for the Israeli public to demand a change

3114.42.text: Whether that looks like annexation or a two state solution,

3117.36.text: I'm not sure, but what will it take for a change

3122.19.text: - First of all no situation is really stagnant.

3131.09.text: In order to move to a two state solution which is

3132.94.text: I think my sense the only solution possible,

3136.23.text: the others are just civil war and anarchy,

3140.37.text: The only way to move to a two state solution

3142.99.text: is to convince the Israeli electorate

3145.54.text: since that's what you asked about,

3147.23.text: is to convince the Israeli electorate

3148.70.text: that by giving up the vast majority of the West Bank

3152.99.text: and east Jerusalem, what you get is end of claims

3156.12.text: and end of conflict which has always been the terms

3158.44.text: of reference meaning, these are going to be the terms

3161.41.text: that we agree upon and there will be no further demands

3163.32.text: and not a maximalist approach that wants

3168.72.text: more than that, meaning all of it.

3173.29.text: They're very, very scared by blurred messages.

3177.71.text: The blurred messages come from either Hamas

3179.52.text: and Fata which are effectively in control

3182.66.text: of two separate territories and voicing those

3185.96.text: conflicting messages, but they're also coming out of

3188.60.text: other arenas in the world like the BDS movement

3192.08.text: for example which is also not coherent.

3194.53.text: It's not clear for people who are activists

3197.99.text: when they say boycott Israel in order to,

3199.96.text: it's not clear what in order to,

3204.69.text: When Palestinians or activists say and the occupation,

3208.49.text: it's not clear what occupation they're referring to.

3210.79.text: Do they want to change the whole character

3212.52.text: of Israel as it was recognized by the UN

3216.94.text: Do they want to have a two state for two people formula

3219.77.text: which is what we've been negotiating on?

3221.39.text: So Israelis don't have clarity on that

3224.16.text: so they vie for the most sure solution

3227.91.text: which is save our security, safeguard us from threats,

3234.15.text: So there needs to be much more coherence

3236.73.text: and this is something that the International community

3239.60.text: They can say these are the points of reference,

3240.88.text: we object to this, we agree to this,

3244.57.text: and that would give maybe the debate more clarity.

3247.40.text: And that would help Israeli's vote for more liberal

3249.98.text: parties I think in the future.

3271.49.text: So you talked a lot about how social media

3273.71.text: has influenced the like younger generation

3276.40.text: of Palestinians and on the front page of the New York Times

3280.04.text: on I think it was Friday, they had an article

3283.74.text: about how they, the reporter has noticed that

3288.37.text: a lot of the music that younger Palestinians are listening

3292.34.text: to is a lot more violent than it has been in the past

3294.95.text: and like, some of the lyrics they talked about

3298.79.text: they mentioned in the article was like encouraging

3303.24.text: I was just wondering if you think this is

3305.36.text: purely rhetoric or if it could have more,

3310.29.text: like real life influence I guess?

3316.01.text: - I don't think it's pure rhetoric because

3317.51.text: we see the effects of it.

3318.90.text: We see people actually stabbing people on the streets

3320.84.text: every day, so it's certainly not pure rhetoric.

3322.87.text: The question, it's like a chicken and an egg question

3325.43.text: Is the music a function of the culture that's prevalent

3329.09.text: and encourages this or does the music reinforce?

3332.78.text: Probably both, I mean it's cyclical.

3337.48.text: all affirm sort of this sense of urgency,

3344.82.text: I mean caricatures like the kinds I've shown you

3346.95.text: display stabbings as something that's glorious,

3351.34.text: that is you know to be encouraged.

3354.71.text: And yeah, I mean the problem is when you talk

3359.69.text: about incitement is in this day and age,

3362.25.text: how do you stop it and where do you target it?

3364.75.text: There are Facebook pages from Gaza

3366.42.text: who have four million followers on Facebook.

3370.30.text: How do you target a person sitting at his home studio

3372.55.text: and recording a song and then sending it out

3378.67.text: How do you fight the ubiquitous internet?

3384.70.text: That's something that many countries are asking

3388.82.text: How do you fight hate speech online?

3391.41.text: Maybe through guidelines on Facebook and Twitter

3393.71.text: but I don't know how stringently those are being enforced.

3395.77.text: I think that's probably the best solution

3397.89.text: because then you could cut out all this stuff

3402.64.text: But I don't know if it's from Mark Zuckerberg

3405.57.text: or the people at Facebook to decide policy

3410.22.text: I mean, maybe it is, I don't know,

3411.57.text: to constitute hate speech, violent images.

3416.92.text: It's really a philosophical question I think

3431.98.text: - [Woman] Thank you so much for your talk.

3434.05.text: So you mentioned that most of the attacks

3437.02.text: have been perpetrated by individuals under

3440.28.text: the age of 22 and you refer to them as

3442.67.text: the Oslo Generation, so I was wondering what

3445.51.text: the internal response was within the Palestinian communities

3449.62.text: of perhaps older generations or the parents,

3452.55.text: older siblings, et cetera, of the terrorists?

3457.68.text: - Well I haven't followed the families so much.

3460.20.text: I did follow some of the political discourse

3462.54.text: and I've followed, I've written a little bit about

3465.02.text: how Fata leaders, I mean Hamas has always encouraged this

3468.30.text: and this is a realization of what they want.

3470.63.text: I was following the people on the second rank

3473.79.text: behind Mahmoud Abbas in the ruling party of the West Bank

3477.59.text: how they're reacting to it, and it's quite startling

3481.94.text: I mean Mahmoud Abbas has spoken out against violence

3484.14.text: and I think he is genuinely against the type of violence

3489.22.text: we saw in the second Intifada.

3491.92.text: But you find almost no other leader speaking out

3495.39.text: about, and even he doesn't do it on principled grounds

3498.95.text: as it is wrong to target innocent civilians in

3503.66.text: People who are very senior in the PA

3506.70.text: and Palestinian authority are saying this is glorious,

3511.20.text: Gebrial Rajub who was the head of Palestinian security

3514.89.text: in the West Bank said that this Will of the Martyr

3518.98.text: that was published by Bahaa Allyan should be taught

3526.49.text: I mean Mahmoud Abbas is an 81 year old chain smoker

3529.20.text: who will not be on the scene for very many more years

3534.00.text: and when you look at the people in the,

3535.46.text: you know, who are slated to replace him,

3539.13.text: for Israelis that doesn't leave very much room

3544.84.text: So that maybe also answers your question

3546.21.text: about Israeli's looking to the future

3549.75.text: and what'll be, you know, if you sign an agreement

3551.55.text: with person X and then tomorrow there's a revolution

3553.97.text: or there's a coup d'etat, who's there to reinforce

3562.21.text: I mean, these are serious questions that can't

3564.22.text: be just disregarded by Israeli belligerents

3568.63.text: They have to be, they have to be addressed.

3570.88.text: So, yeah, it's worrying on the West Bank.

3586.95.text: - [Man] Thank you for the talk and thank you

3588.77.text: Quick question about an update on the

3592.38.text: I don't know if one calls them temporary or not,

3594.44.text: but the newly installed barriers that have been placed

3597.53.text: in some of the Palestinian neighborhoods

3599.42.text: in Jerusalem as a response to the attacks

3603.78.text: and my question is how thoroughly has that measure

3608.35.text: been implemented and is it your sense that

3611.34.text: those barriers are temporary or is there the possibility

3615.44.text: that they could become a more permanent fixture

3618.67.text: - Okay, that's a really good question

3619.79.text: that a lot of Israelis are asking themselves now.

3621.93.text: Sort of the main line of the current government

3625.61.text: was Jerusalem is never to be divided,

3628.06.text: it's the eternal capital, et cetera,

3629.73.text: and then in the recent weeks we see

3632.61.text: they're basically, they're not even roadblocks.

3635.94.text: They're basically concrete cubes that are placed

3638.31.text: on the entrances to some of the Palestinian neighborhoods

3641.13.text: where soldiers then vet drivers coming in and out

3647.15.text: It's a way of sort of making sure that attackers

3651.93.text: Now some people have correctly identified that

3654.85.text: as at least this showing that you can divide Jerusalem.

3658.70.text: Because if you are placing blocks and separating

3663.68.text: then you're showing that Jerusalem can be divided.

3667.92.text: Israel already did presumably show that by erecting

3670.52.text: the separation or the security barrier in 2002

3673.62.text: which cuts off a number of neighborhoods

3676.96.text: that are part of Jerusalem behind the wall,

3681.44.text: So those neighborhoods have already defacto

3686.21.text: That's why, so first of all I think that these cubes

3689.24.text: are going to be removed once things calm down

3692.61.text: They have been placed in the past

3696.71.text: They bring them, they remove them,

3698.12.text: a few days or a week later, they don't stay,

3701.02.text: but they do prove that you can if you want to

3704.09.text: seal of neighborhoods, but these measures have been

3707.78.text: severely criticized by people on the ideological rights,

3710.72.text: both in the Lekud Party, the Prime Minister's party

3714.07.text: and people in city hall who are from the right

3716.55.text: who say Netanyahu, you're showing people that Jerusalem

3720.64.text: You're actually dividing Jerusalem so stop

3725.94.text: And I think, I think this is more directed

3729.70.text: by police policy than from up top,

3734.13.text: but it has to be authorized by the Prime Minister.

3738.43.text: On the one hand you want to take care

3739.41.text: of the security of the people in the city.

3741.62.text: On the other hand you don't want to send

3744.99.text: How do you weigh one against the other?

3748.05.text: It's a tricky, tricky trade off I would say.

3750.93.text: But I don't think that the blocks that you've

3753.06.text: read about today for example in articles,

3755.56.text: or about these road blocks are going to stay.

3757.08.text: They're not going to be permanent.

3764.65.text: - [Man] So I understand that in your work

3766.11.text: you actually worked on creating inter-religious

3768.72.text: dialogue between the Palestinian and the Jews

3770.86.text: and I was wondering if you could talk more about that

3773.85.text: and how you think such, more of such inter-religious

3777.99.text: - Less than with my work, more as a student,

3780.93.text: so it's been a few years now, dialogues like this

3784.78.text: go on all the time in Israel and in Jerusalem specifically.

3792.81.text: I mean we don't, Jews and Palestinians don't live

3796.94.text: That's also changing by the way, but they share

3799.76.text: many spaces, they share the University campuses,

3802.14.text: they share courts, they share hospitals

3805.03.text: both as patients and as doctors from both sides.

3807.61.text: They share, you know higher education,

3812.21.text: You know, you go to Jaffa Street in Jerusalem,

3815.05.text: you see many, many head scarves, and you know,

3819.37.text: and there have been actually infrastructure changes

3823.64.text: in Jerusalem that enable that process.

3825.81.text: A few years ago, a light rail, a tram was built

3828.48.text: in Jerusalem that connects Palestinian neighborhoods

3830.80.text: into West Jerusalem and allows a huge amount

3834.74.text: of Palestinians to enter freely into West Jerusalem,

3840.92.text: So there is a shared space and there's,

3845.54.text: there's a need from below to have these sort

3850.35.text: People feel that they don't know the other side well enough.

3852.05.text: Sometimes it's even the language barrier.

3856.24.text: People who have Palestinian high school diplomas

3858.81.text: and want to live in Jerusalem and study in Jerusalem

3861.22.text: need to qualify, need to study Hebrew.

3868.57.text: Unfortunate, I mean the opposite is also true

3870.84.text: to some extent, but it's more of a fringe phenomenon.

3873.70.text: It's a bit of a hipster kind of Jews wanting

3875.63.text: to learn Arabic because they don't need it

3877.60.text: as much as a tool for daily life.

3879.68.text: Jews don't need Arabic to get along,

3884.09.text: as a tool for employment, for buying things.

3888.01.text: The Palestinian economy is very much more dependent

3889.71.text: on Israel than the other way around.

3891.40.text: So dialogue I think is always good.

3895.47.text: I think it's a way of mitigating violence

3897.39.text: even if you don't reach political agreements

3901.93.text: The Jews and Arabs can reach like a documented solution

3905.26.text: from my experience, but once you speak to someone

3909.23.text: and you hear about his or her fears, narratives,

3911.72.text: then you can't demonize them as easily.

3914.05.text: I don't think that somebody who's spent seven

3916.20.text: or eight months speaking to an Israeli will go

3919.25.text: and stab an Israeli on the street.

3921.12.text: That's my belief and that's why these things

3924.46.text: are important and should be encouraged even in

3931.24.text: we have for questions for tonight

3932.85.text: so please join me in thanking Mr. Miller
